description.narrative: Contribute to improved protection of civilians in CAR, Mali and DRC through humanitarian mediation processes aiming at conflict prevention and mitigation.

NRC develops and implements Humanitarian Mediation in Mali, CAR and DRC. Based on conflict sensitive context analyses, mediation teams facilitate or lead inclusive dialogue and mediation on local level to reduce risks and vulnerabilities to armed conflict.

Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC) genomför och utvecklar humanitär medling i konfliktdrabbade samhällen i CAR, DRK och Mali. Utifrån konfliktkänsliga kontextanalyser arbetar specialutbildade medlingsteam för att facilitera och leda inklusiv dialog och medling på lokal nivå för att minska risken för och utsatthet för våldsam konflikt. Till insatsen hör också en lärandekomponent för att dokumentera och fånga upp erfarenheter och kunskap till förmån för den bredare dialogen kring skärningspunkten humanitär verksamhet och fredsbyggande.
Bedömningspromemorian skrivs på engelska med anledning av att engelskspråkig personal i Fält är delaktig i beredning och uppföljning av insatsen, i enlighet med Generaldirektörens beslut om Sidas språkvalsmatris med tillämpningsanvisningar från den l mars 2013.

sector.narrative: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution

tag.narrative: 16.1 - Avsevärt minska alla former av våld och dödligt våld överallt.
16.1 - Significantly reduce all forms of violence and related death rates everywhere.
16.7 - Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört, inkluderande, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: In the three countries of implementation - the CAR, Mali and the DRC, needs of displaced populations include security and safety. Though this program, NRC have piloted a method to contribute to preventing violence and supporting cohesion on community level; Humanitarian mediation. The programme has piloted activities aimed at reducing immediate tensions and mitigate conflicts at the community level in the three programme countries. Mediation processes in Mali, DRC and CAR have been used to address a variety of community concerns and tensions, including: Tensions between returning IDPs and host community, secondary occupants and local armed groups. / Tensions and conflicts between herders, crop farmers and displaced people over the use of resources (land, water) and the destruction of crops through cattle movement and grazing. / Tensions relating to the distribution and application of customary power between two communities. Across the three countries, a total of 11 meditations were undertaken, with preparatory pre-mediation sessions commenced to address a further 45 conflicts (but did not proceed to mediation). Prior to commencing pre-mediation processes, 48 conflict sensitive, gender and protection analyses were conducted, informing not only the mediation initiative, but providing an evidence base to inform broader protection programming in these contexts. The total number of 2,235 direct-unique beneficiaries benefited directly from the HMI (837 (CAR), 314 (DRC) and 1084 (Mali). Across the three countries, more than two thirds of community members in targeted areas reported feeling safer and more secure at the end of the initiative, with a similar number of participants reporting positive changes in relationships with other participants (75%). In addition to the delivery of meditations, this initiative also strengthened capacities in each of the three targeted countries, ensuring that community members in the targeted communities have increased knowledge, skills and experience to support future mediation work and to train additional mediation actors. The initiative has also contributed to learning in this area and provides an important evidence base on which to design and implement future mediation work within NRC.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
